item.title: Manage common threats, risks, and vulnerabilities
item.description: Risk management A primary goal of organizations is to protect assets. An asset is an item perceived as having value to an organization. Assets can be digital or physical. Examples of digital assets include the personal information of employees, clients, or vendors, such as: Social Security Numbers (SSNs), or unique national identification numbers assigned to individuals Dates of birth Bank account numbers Mailing addresses Examples of physical assets include: Payment kiosks Servers Desktop computers Office spaces Some common strategies used to manage risks include:

item.title: Security domains cybersecurity analysts need to know
item.description: Domain one: Security and risk management All organizations must develop their security posture. Security posture is an organizationâ€™s ability to manage its defense of critical assets and data and react to change. Elements of the security and risk management domain that impact an organization’s security posture include: Security goals and objectives Risk mitigation processes Compliance Business continuity plans Legal regulations Professional and organizational ethics Information security, or InfoSec, is also related to this domain and refers to a set of processes established to secure information.

item.title: Markdown flavors
item.description: Markdown flavors Markdown flavors are variations or extensions of the original Markdown syntax, designed to offer additional functionality or slightly different syntax rules. Different platforms and applications often use their own custom Markdown flavors to suit their specific needs. Here are some common flavors of Markdown: Standard Markdown Developer: John Gruber Features: Basic features like headers, lists, links, and inline formatting. Notable: This is the original Markdown specification. CommonMark Developer: Community effort led by John MacFarlane Features: A standardized and unambiguous version of Markdown.

item.title: Markdown
item.description: Introduction You may well have heard of Markdown, but itâ€™s okay if you havenâ€™t. The typical way that users first might encounter Markdown is through formatting text on internet message boards. You might have encountered it used on GitHub in readme files, at the very least. A professional use for Markdown is to write technical documentation. Technical writers have a dazzling array of options for producing their documentation. Thatâ€™s why many writers opt for Markdown â€“ itâ€™s easy to use, and adaptable between different platforms (at least, in theory).
